title.children: 'We are frightened in our own home': Jane is part of a growing campaign to stop kangaroo culling

image.altText: A cylindrical white metal underwater craft floats in a dark blue mass of water.

items.synopsis: Search efforts are continuing for five people missing in a deep-ocean submersible in the northern Atlantic, with rescuers in a race against time as oxygen levels dwindle.

title.children: All passengers on board missing Titanic submersible identified as breathable air dwindles

image.altText: Australia batter Pat Cummins shouts in joy after winning an Ashes Test at Edgbaston.

items.synopsis: Pat Cummins leads Australia to a stunning victory in the first Ashes Test, chasing down 281 with just two wickets left inside the final five overs at Edgbaston.

title.children: Pat Cummins leads Australia to miraculous Ashes victory with thrilling run chase at Edgbaston

image.altText: England fielder Ben Stokes drops the ball as he hits the ground.

items.synopsis: An inquiry hears a NSW Police task force ruled there was "insufficient information" to establish whether the former AC/DC manager's death was a hate crime but it had not tested his blood-stained clothes.

title.children: Bloody clothes left untested by police for 30 years could solve mystery of who killed AC/DC manager

image.altText: police crash investigators inspect the  road at the site of a crash

items.synopsis: The NSW government orders its Bus Industry Taskforce to review concerns around seat belt use, driver training and fatigue and safety management.

title.children: Urgent review ordered into NSW bus safety after fatal Hunter Valley crash

image.altText: A rainbow-coloured sign advertising the cancellation of an event.

items.synopsis: When organisers first convinced traditionally conservative parts of the country to host a Pride ball, it was celebrated as a win for inclusion. Now thriving, these events are increasingly facing a new and sinister threat.

title.children: Far right groups and conspiracy theorists forcing shutdowns of pride events in growing trend

items.synopsis: Reports that scientists are making "synthetic embryos" has revived debate about stem cell research. But what exactly is going on?

title.children: Scientists created 'synthetic embryos' without sperm or eggs. What are the legal and ethical implications?

title.children: 'You deserve no mercy': Experienced judge shocked by man's 'horrendous' sexual abuse of stepdaughter

image.altText: A woman holds a jar filled with Fantales lollies.

title.children: 'What do we put in the lolly jar now?': End of an era as Nestlé calls a wrap on Fantales

items.synopsis: A major new opinion poll shows Australians have warmed slightly to China over the past year, while a majority are glad to see high-level political contact between Canberra and Beijing resume.

title.children: Majority of Australians believe China could pose a military threat to Australian within 20 years, poll finds

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian inquiry hears disturbing accounts of children being injected and given ice by parents wanting them to commit crimes.

title.children: 'You poor little thing': Parents injecting kids with ice to commit crimes, inquiry hears

image.altText: Signage at a Telstra store in Sydney.

items.synopsis: It has been red across the board on global markets, with China's rate cut disappointing and traders awaiting testimony from the Federal Reserve chair. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Telstra-TPG regional network deal blocked, ASX in the red, Aussie dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld a decision to block a network sharing agreement between major telcos Telstra and TPG. The deal would've seen TPG decommission or transfer regional mobile sites, and then acquire mobile services from Telstra. TPG says it would've increased its mobile network coverage from 96 per cent to 98.8 per cent of the Australian population. At the end of last year, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission rejected the plans, arguing there was a real risk it would reduce investment in infrastructure. Telstra and TPG challenged the decision but now the Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld it. "This determination entrenches the status quo for mobile coverage in regional Australia," TPG boss Iñaki Berroeta said today. TPG is now considering its options for a further appeal. At the time it blocked the sharing deal, the ACCC said there would be some short-term benefits in improving TPG's network coverage, but that it could lessen infrastructure-based competition. "Competition between separate mobile networks drives companies to improve coverage for mobile users and to offer new technologies to more areas. "For example, when Optus improves its regional network, Telstra responds by improving its network to maintain its market position," ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said in December. "Infrastructure competition is what drives investments by mobile companies in broader, deeper and faster mobile coverage… We have concluded the proposed arrangements would likely significantly weaken this competitive process."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TPG - Telstra regional network sharing deal blocked

children.content: The
Australian Competition Tribunal
has upheld a decision to block a network sharing agreement between major telcos
Telstra
and
TPG.
The deal would've seen TPG decommission or transfer regional mobile sites, and then acquire mobile services from Telstra.
TPG says it would've increased its mobile network coverage from 96 per cent to 98.8 per cent of the Australian population.
At the end of last year, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission rejected the plans, arguing there was a real risk it would reduce investment in infrastructure.
Telstra and TPG challenged the decision but now the Australian Competition Tribunal has upheld it.
"This determination entrenches the status quo for mobile coverage in regional Australia," TPG boss Iñaki Berroeta said today.
TPG is now considering its options for a further appeal.
At the time it blocked the sharing deal, the ACCC said there would be some short-term benefits in improving TPG's network coverage, but that it could lessen infrastructure-based competition.
"Competition between separate mobile networks drives companies to improve coverage for mobile users and to offer new technologies to more areas.
"For example, when Optus improves its regional network, Telstra responds by improving its network to maintain its market position," ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said in December.

"Infrastructure competition is what drives investments by mobile companies in broader, deeper and faster mobile coverage… We have concluded the proposed arrangements would likely significantly weaken this competitive process."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's early days for the local session but the share market has so far lost ground, with the All Ordinaries down around 0.3 per cent. There are some falls for iron ore miners, including a 2 per cent drop for Fortescue shares. This morning Fortescue updated the market, saying executive chairman Andrew Forrest had transferred ownership of around $5 billion worth of shares (220 million FMG shares) to his philanthropic venture, the Minderoo Foundation — that's one-fifth of the family's holding in the miner. Gold mining stocks are also under pressure, including Silver Lake Resources (-4%). And TPG Telecom shares have slumped more than 8 per cent on news the Australian Competition Tribunal has blocked a regional network sharing arrangement with Telstra. Telstra shares are up 0.6 per cent. It's a better session for consumer stocks, with some retailers on the rise including Woolworths (+0.7%) and Coles (+0.9%). Here's how the sectors are faring:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's an interesting long-form read for your morning — a deep dive into the fight between commercial kangaroo shooters and kangaroo leather exporters, and animal welfare advocates. Commercial shooters are regulated under a national code that’s supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach and cruel. At the same time, US politicians are moving to phase out the use of kangaroo leather and several global sportswear brands have already stepped away from its use. It's left exporters fighting to protect their industry. Nassim Khadem explores it from all angles here — a warning, the story contains graphic vision and images that may be distressing to the viewer:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The fight over commercial kangaroo shooting

featuredLink.title: 'We are frightened in our own home': Jane is part of a growing campaign to stop kangaroo culling

children.content: Here's an interesting long-form read for your morning — a deep dive into
the fight between commercial kangaroo shooters
and kangaroo leather exporters, and
animal welfare advocates
Commercial shooters are regulated under a national code that’s supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach and cruel.
At the same time, US politicians are moving to phase out the use of kangaroo leather and several global sportswear brands have already stepped away from its use.
A billboard in California as part of the "kangaroos are not shoes" campaign.
It's left exporters fighting to protect their industry.
Nassim Khadem
explores it from all angles here —
